section.title: Replacing a Standalone Controller Node

para.para: If the controller node you need to replace is not also being used as the lifecycle manager then you will use these steps.

section.para: If the controller node you need to replace is not also being used as the lifecycle manager then you will use these steps:,

listitem.para: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Update your cloud model, specifically the servers.yml file, with the new mac-addr, ilo-ip, ilo-password, and ilo-user fields where these have changed. Do not change the id, ip-addr, role, or server-group settings.
Commit your configuration to the , as follows:
listitem.screen: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible git add -A git commit -m "My config or other commit message"

listitem.para: Remove the old controller node(s) from Cobbler. You can list out the systems in Cobbler currently with this command:
and then remove the old controller nodes with this command:
Remove the SSH key of the old controller node from the known hosts file. You will specify the ip-addr value:
You should see a response similar to this one:
listitem.screen: stack@helion-cp1-c1-m1-mgmt:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ssh-keygen -f "/home/stack/.ssh/known_hosts" -R 10.13.111.135 # Host 10.13.111.135 found: line 6 type ECDSA /home/stack/.ssh/known_hosts updated. Original contents retained as /home/stack/.ssh/known_hosts.old

listitem.para: Run the cobbler-deploy playbook to add the new controller node:
Image the new node(s) by using the bm-reimage playbook. You will specify the name for the node in Cobbler in the command:

important.para: You must ensure that the old controller node is powered off before completing this step. This is because the new controller node will re-use the original IP address.

listitem.para: Configure the necessary keys used for the database etc:
Run osconfig on the replacement controller node. For example:
If the controller being replaced is the Swift ring builder (see ) you need to restore the Swift ring builder files to the /etc/swiftlm/builder_dir directory. See for details.
Run the hlm-deploy playbook on the replacement controller.

If the node being replaced is the Swift ring builder server then you only need to use the --limit switch for that node, otherwise you need to specify the hostname of your Swift ringer builder server and the hostname of the node being replaced.

important.para: If you receive a RabbitMQ failure when running this playbook, review for how to resolve the issue and then re-run the hlm-deploy playbook.

listitem.para: During the replacement of the node there will be alarms that show up during the process. If those do not clear after the node is back up and healthy, restart the threshold engine by running the following playbooks:
listitem.screen: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-stop.yaml --tags thresh ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts monasca-start.yaml --tags thresh
